Second, specifically discerning the destinies of rebirth, in two parts:

In all worlds, the continuation of birth and death is that life follows habitual tendencies and death follows transformation. At the time of death, before the warmth of the body is lost, the good and evil of a lifetime suddenly appear together. Death goes against life, and the two habits intersect.
There are two kinds of going with and going against:

First, in terms of emotions, all sentient beings love life and hate death. Life is in accord with emotions, and death goes against emotions. Therefore, it is said that life follows habitual tendencies and death follows transformation. Transformation is the same as going against.

Second, in terms of karma, karma can produce effects. Life is in accord with what is produced, because the cause leads to the effect. Therefore, it is said to follow habitual tendencies;
Death is the opposite of this, and there is no meaning of growth. Therefore, it is said to follow transformation.

At the juncture of life and death, before the wind and fire disperse, the good and evil causes and conditions of a lifetime all appear at this time. The stronger one pulls first, and one follows the place of birth.
Second, specifically clarifying the rise and fall of emotions and thoughts, in five parts:

Those with dull thoughts will fly up and certainly be reborn in the heavens.

If in the mind of flying there is both blessings, wisdom, and pure vows, the mind will naturally open up and see the Buddhas of the ten directions, and one will be reborn in the pure lands according to one's wishes.

If in upholding precepts one also cultivates blessings and wisdom, gives rise to the vow to see the Buddha, and deeply detests the three realms, one will certainly be reborn in the pure lands.
Seeing the Buddhas of the ten directions one immediately attains the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, thus it is said the mind opens, as explained in the Guanjing.
Second, with few emotions and many thoughts.

With few emotions and many thoughts, one lightly ascends and does not go far, becoming a flying immortal, a powerful ghost king, a flying yaksha, a ground-roaming rakshasa, roaming the four heavens, going wherever one wishes without obstruction.
Because of the abundance of thoughts, they have mastery over flight, but because of the paucity of emotions, they take on the form of celestial ghosts.

If among them there are those with good aspirations, good minds, who uphold my Dharma, or who protect the precepts and follow those who uphold the precepts, or who protect the divine spells and follow those who uphold the spells, or who protect meditative absorption and support the acceptance of the Dharma, these will be close to the TathÄgata's seat.
This means that among those with abundant thoughts, there are also those with good aspirations.

Although they do not uphold precepts, they still have concentration and vows. Third, equal emotions and thoughts.
With equal emotions and thoughts, one neither flies up nor falls down, but is born among humans.
Those with clear thoughts are wise, while those with dark emotions are dull.
Not ascending to become celestial immortals, not falling into the three evil paths, still within the state of equality,
if thoughts are slightly stronger, the faculties must be wise;
if emotions are slightly heavier, the faculties must be dull.
Although the same human species, there are still differences in emotions and thoughts, which is the separate retribution.

With many emotions and few thoughts, one flows into sideways births, becoming heavy as a herd animal or light as a bird.

If discussed in detail, the distinctions are as explained in the section on birth according to type and in the following text.
Seven emotions and three thoughts sink into the water wheel and are born at the edge of fire.
Receiving the qi of fierce fire, one becomes a hungry ghost, constantly being burned.
Water can harm oneself, without food or drink for hundreds of thousands of kalpas.
The edge of fire is the place where hungry ghosts dwell. The water wheel goes down to the edge of the fire wheel, close to hell.

Water can harm oneself means suffering from lack of water. If one encounters it, it turns into fire and burns one's body, hence called harming oneself.
Nine emotions and one thought sink down to the fire wheel, entering the place where wind and fire intersect, giving rise to the two kinds of hells of light existence and rebirth without interval.

Slightly more is called heavy, entering the hell without interval, which is the full nine emotions.
This refers to the hell without interval from the perspective of suffering.

If in the sinking mind there is slander of the Mahayana, denigration of the Buddha's precepts, deceptive preaching of the Dharma, falsely coveting offerings and respect, and the five heinous crimes and ten grave offenses, one will be reborn in the AvÄ«ci hells of the ten directions.
